Posts.Content: Apr 10, 2008 07:25AM - edited Apr 10, 2008 09:39AM by RoxanneNJ31 Hi, i had denials for my ct/pet and bone scans on numerous occasions.  i contacted the insurance company direct and spoke to many supervisors who said they have an outsource (Aetna) who approves or denys just like that.  I contacted them and fought and fought and even got my insurance case nurse manager involved and now it seems they are approving all of them every three months with now fight. They were denying radiologist doctor charges because they said it was out of my network when I was going to the hospital (innetwork). I explained to them that I have no control over which doctor reads my scans and after three phone calls they said you are right and reversed the charges.  Its a shame that we have to fight for every bit of our treatment My advice be persistent and make sure you let them know that the answer no is not going to fly with you, that you will contact them as much as you have to and even threaten them with the Department of Insurance and Banking Department in your home state.  If we don't take charge or our own lives then the insurnace and legislators will take control of it for us and that will give us inadequate and limited care that we need to survive. We are a strong community and need to fight for us and ours since no one else seems to care. If you need help in your fight please contact me direct and I will do what I can to help you because we deserve the best treatment options available. Good luck and many hugs.

Posts.Content: RoxanneNJ31 wrote: Please read and talk to your onc if you are on this drug like me:  FDA panel recommends against approving Genentech's Avastin for breast cancer Published: Wednesday, December 5, 2007 | 6:53 PM ET Canadian Press: Matthew Perrone, THE ASSOCIATED PRESS WASHINGTON - A panel of U.S. government experts said Wednesday that Genentech's cancer drug should not be approved for expanded use in breast-cancer patients. The Food and Drug Administration's advisers voted five to four against the new use, on grounds that the benefits of the treatment did not outweigh potential risks. The agency does not have to follow the advice of its panel, though it usually does. Initially approved in 2004 to treat colon cancer, Avastin was the first drug to fight cancer by stopping nutrients from reaching tumours. Such "targeted therapies" were thought to hold promise for eliminating chemotherapy, but that promise remains unmet. South San Francisco-based Genentech Inc. asked the FDA to approve the drug for use alongside chemotherapy in patients with advanced breast cancer who have not already taken other drugs. While some doctors already use the drug to treat breast cancer, FDA approval would have increased the practice significantly. Avastin, which is also approved to treat types of lung cancer, was the company's second best-selling product last year with sales of US$1.7 billion. "We are disappointed by the split vote of the advisory committee," Susan Desmond-Hellmann, Genentech's head of product development, said in a statement. "We believe that Avastin can help meet a significant unmet medical need for women with metastatic breast cancer."Continue Article Prior to the meeting, FDA scientists said that while Avastin slowed the progression of cancer, it did not improve patients' life span overall. Patients on Avastin and chemotherapy survived on average 26.5 months, compared with 24.8 months for patients taking just chemotherapy. FDA said the difference was not significant. Scientists also questioned the drug's safety. Patients on Avastin had 20 per cent higher toxicity levels than those on chemotherapy. Common side effects included hypertension and blood clots. The panel's decision has implications for all drug makers working on cancer therapies. Increasingly, the FDA wants to see overall survival rates improve - not just the delay of cancer's progression - before it grants U.S. approval. Avastin, long a recipient of superstar treatment and heavy touting in the Genentech portfolio, has also got the attention of increasingly competitive rivals. Earlier in the year, Britain's GlaxoSmithKline received approval for Tykerb to treat patients with advanced breast cancer. The FDA is scheduled to make its final decision on Avastin in February. While most analysts leaned against an approval decision for the drug Wednesday, Morgan Stanley's Steven Harr suggested the FDA could show some leeway given the narrow panel vote. Harr also pointed out that of the five cancer specialists on the panel, four favoured approval. Dx 6/5/2007, 4cm, Stage IV, Grade 3, 2/30 nodes, mets, ER+/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Oct 25, 2007 09:28AM RoxanneNJ31 wrote: Hi, i am sorry for your stress.  It is hard enought to deal with cancer but when you have to add in other factors the stress is truly overwhelming and dehibilitating. I was on zoloft for only 2 months when I decided to take myself off.  i like your husband had allot of issues with the drug. I am now in counseling and only take xanax when i am having a sever panic attack.  I felt like it was changing me, that i was looking at myself from the outside. My mom has been on anti depressents for as long as I remember. Paxil then zoloft. Finally after 5 years I convinced her that the zoloft and paxil were making her worse.  i made her change her doctor adn she is now on lexapro.  This is truely her wonder drug.  The transformation was amazing.  Maybe you should have your husband talk to his doctor to change the meds to lexapro. Maybe it would be right for him as well. Please remember especially because us women take on way more then what men do because we are raised as the caregivers and a lot of the time we give away too much are really the one who needs the support as cancer is a very tricky and hard diease to overcome. You need all your strength and energy to fight the green eyed monster (cancer) and need all the outside outlets you can. i hope it all works out with your husband but just know if you ever need strength in numbers the breast cancer sisters are here for you.
Posts.Title: DH having a "hard time" badboob67 Fllorik

Posts.Content: Apr 24, 2008 01:28PM RoxanneNJ31 wrote: HI Bad booobs, i too had a similiar decision when I wa sfirst diagnosed with bone mets.  The doctor felt that Avastin and abraxene along with zometa was my best choice.  I told him that I didn't want to lose my hair and so against his better judgement he said ok xeloda and advastin was ok.  He said worst came to worst we could switch.  Well I got my xeloda prescription and went to the doctor for my first advastin treatment and something made me switch. I am a year into treatment, he dropped my abraxene and so far Im holding stable with no progression. You have to make the choice for you and their is no right or wrong answer, its whatever your most positive about because the mind something plays heavy in your overrall well being and response to treatment (at least thats what I think and sticking to it lol). So good luck and many hugs. PS I never did lose my hair on the abraxene.  See how sometimes your strong will helps he he.  Anyway, again take care and good luck.  I know youll do fine. Roxanne

Posts.Content: Apr 18, 2008 07:38PM RoxanneNJ31 wrote: Deb, No way did you overreact at all. Its your body and at the end of the day, you have the right to "fire" a nurse. These nurses forget that we are human.  How would they like to be poked and repoked time and time again. I remember i went to the emergency room and this arrogant nurse said oh we can't use your lymph arm i was like no then she was looking for a vein and found on that was ovverused from chemo, i said to her you can't use that vein it doesn't work, it seems to you like a good vein but its dead.  She kept insisting to use that vein.  2 times and a huge black and blue later she was like oh your right.   I then refused to get my blood drawn until a phelbotomist came down and i heard them all snickering.  I was livid i got up and said are you kidding me you should be ashamed of yourself, i told you not to use the vein and you you still did.  Then you have the nerve to talk about me.  I was like you know what you are not worth it.  I called my doctors office and told him i would never go through that emergency again because of the situation, i told him if I am ever in the hospital that he will have to travel to the other hospital.  His office was so mad that appartently the nurse was reprimanded.  I am so happy that she was reprimanded but felt so guilty but at the end of the day maybe she will realize that you can't treat people that way. Sorry for your aggravation but good thing that she got in trouble.  Unsanitary needles lead to bad bad things. Take care
Posts.Title: Did I over react? FIred a nurse yesterday.... AlaskaDeb snowyday

Posts.Content: May 9, 2008 01:02PM RoxanneNJ31 wrote: I can totally relate. I was dx'ed at 31 with 2a breast cancer and at 33 I was dxed with bone mets.  Sometimes, I feel that why me, while my friends are out partying im exhausted, taking chemo and always have some medical thing to do. But the one thing I always remind myself is im still here to complain and feel sorry for myself. I have been on chemo and other drugs since last year for the bone mets.  I was on abraxene, advastin, zometa and zoladex (to stop period).  The doctor dropped the abraxene after 8 months so now I am stable and on maintenence drugs. It is ok to feel sorry for yourself and be tired.  You are allowed to have these days believe me, we always dont' have to be superwomen. I have bad days all the time but what I try to remember is Im alive and every month I am stable they are working on the cure so hopefully soon enough we will not have to deal with this. If you need to talk or need any information, please feel free to PM me. I totally understand what you are going through.

Posts.Content: May 7, 2008 01:36PM RoxanneNJ31 wrote: HI, I am so sorry you are feeling crappy.  I was on advastin, zometa, and abraxene and still on the first two. I was on abraxene on three off one for 8 months (24 alltogether) and now we are trying maintenece. I guess I was the lucky one, I didnt' get the hair loss and the only effects i got was a metal taste in my mouth for three days after chemo ( even water tasted gross), i ate allot of spicy foods, chocolate and tea seemed to be ok.  the other major side effect I got was extreme fatigue which I am still fighting, I don't know if its the other drugs im still on or if its my crazy life style. If you are experiencing side effects that are too much to handle, talk to the onc and see if you both could come up with a solution.  YOu shouldn't have to feel crappy on top of fighting this stupid diease. Hope I helped. Take care and many soft hugs for you. Roxanne

Posts.Content: RoxanneNJ31 wrote: Hi Breast Cancer Sisters, I am on a crusade and need your help.  I have been writing all day to everyone from the news, to Oprah and Montell to President Bush regarding SSI and Medicare.  it is so unfortunate that Stage IV Cancer survivors must wait 2 years to receive medical coverage. Why is the waiting period so long when we are considered to be permanently disabled and desperately need the coverage for survival.  It sickens me that we are not covered immediately.  I am a stage iv survior and take very expensive chemo and drugs to survive but I cannot quit my job to take proper care of myself.  I am in constant pain but make too much to qualify for medicaid and not enough to afford 500 a month for medical premiums, its just not fair. so i plug away at work even though i know that I should be home in bed but whats my alternative.  I am single 34 and have no options. So as I was thinking about it it dawned on me, I am one voice but there are so many others like me.  Lets all write to everyone we can and make them hear that we will not stand for this anymore.  We deserve to be treated humanely and with the utmost respect and medical care. Please lets all stick together and get what we need, proper medical insurance and monies to survive this terrible diease.  We did not ask for Cancer but we need to survive and the government is not giving us the proper outlets. Thank you for taking the time to read this and I hope we all fight this together because one voice is overlooked but many are heard. All my love and hugs go out to my cancer sisters and brothers.... Roxanne Dx 6/5/2007, 4cm, Stage IV, Grade 3, 2/30 nodes, mets, ER+/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Apr 21, 2008 09:42PM RoxanneNJ31 wrote: You know, We are the "dirty little secret", Breast Cancer patients are getting younger and younger and our governement does not want to face the fact that is not just genetic anymore. I am 34  and didn't have the gene ,  it seems that women 19, 20 and so forth are getting this diease at alarming increasing rates. its real nice to have the walks and the think pink everywhere but where is the relief to the women already diagnosed. It is not the 1920's and the Government needs to reconize that we need medical care.  If we all stick together, then we can make our voice heard.  Enough is enough.  We are sick and tired literally and the reality is,  we need the medical care now, not in 30 years now.  Why not give us the care we need now...... Its just not right and I hope that change goin to come soon.... Thanks for listening. Roxanne

Posts.Content: May 12, 2008 02:35PM RoxanneNJ31 wrote: I lost my hair in my first treatment adryimican/cytoxen and taxol treatment (2005).   At first I was scared knowing that I would be bald but once it happened, I didn't mind being bald as much as I though, I just came to accept it because I knew it was part of my goal to get better.  I would walk around bald but I would get the i feel so bad for you looks (dxed at 31), and actually many older people would feel bad. So to apease the people around me i would wear the scarf but the truth of the matter was is I didn't mind being bald, no hair to do in the morning was a treat. I would wake up 15 minutes before I had to leave take a shower and go no fuss no mess. i even went as far as being "Uncle Fester" for halloween since I have a crazy humor and also walking around telling people rub the buddah but that how i deal with things, trying to stay postive and making light of every situation. Everyone deals with situations different and the only advise that i have for you is that whatever you feel we all empthasis.  No feeling is right or wrong. I feel terrible that you or any of us have to go through this but know you have us here to support you and hopefully we can be your strength to get through any ups and downs you have. I know now that if I do lose my hair again, I do not care what people say or do, i will be bald and proud to be bald because I am still here. Sorry I didn't have better tips. Many hugs, Roxanne

Posts.Content: Apr 3, 2008 04:17PM RoxanneNJ31 wrote: Hi badboob, It really sucks that you have to go throught the Chemo but chemo isn't as bad as it once was or so I am told.  I also have bone mets (11 bones) and when my doctor and I had the "talk" he gave me both options: 1. xeloda, advastin, zometa and zoladex or 2. Abraxane, advastin, zometa and zoladex. His recomendation was the 2. (Abraxene) because of the fast progession.  I was on Abraxene for 8 months and now have some decrease in the mets but the blessing is that it is stable.  Now I am just on what he calls maintenence and its all the drugs listed in 2. but the abraxene.  I am doing very well haven't had too many side effects and the pain has ceased (had bad pain in my shoulder and back).  I am very grateful for this onc since he was my second onc and did what he said he was going to do stabilize my mets. Good luck and many hugs and if you need to talk, please pm me and I will be happy to help in whatever way I can. Take care. Roxanne

I am so confused and really am not ready for all this again. I just don't have the energy for being sick. I was always positive but im having a really hard time with going through all this again. God bless each and everyone of us!!! Live for today, tomorrow and for as long as were blessed on this earth...
